title: Restaurant Ordering System
description: Most restaurants had inefficient customer service, as researchers found. Calling customers by name or number, though it may work in small places, could slow things down and get confusing. This might be okay for small eateries, but as businesses grow, manual monitoring could become a problem.
problem: When helping clients in a busy and chaotic place, staff faced understandable challenges. Manual work took too long and got stressful as more customers came in, so it wasn't a viable solution. Customers got frustrated because it was hard to grab staff attention for help. If tables weren't cleared, customers waited longer, creating an ongoing delay.
answer: To address the issue, researchers suggested a Restaurant Ordering System. This system would track occupied tables, bills, customer needs, and finished meals, reducing the need for physical monitoring. This allowed staff to focus on tasks and avoid distractions.
functions: Real-time table status display with color-coded indicators (Red – Occupied, Green – Unoccupied, Yellow – Needs assistance, Blue – Dirty, Grey – Not connected to the device, Purple – Connecting to the device)
Table timer to track dining duration
Order tracking with detailed order history
Point-of-Sale (POS) food ordering system with item customization
Update order quantity and display total cost in real-time
Menu management (add, update, or delete food items)
Real-time order queue for kitchen staff
Order processing system with completion and cancellation options
Account registration with role-based access control
improvements: Customer feedback system for gathering and analyzing reviews
Data analytics and reporting for sales, popular items, and staff performance
Customizable promotional offers and discounts engine
Integration with payment gateways for multiple payment options

process.title: Discovery & Research
details: Conduct interviews with restaurant owners and staff to identify operational problems
Observe customer flow and service processes to understand pain points
Gather insights from existing systems and competitors
Define the project scope based on the restaurant’s specific needs

process.title: Ideation & Concept
details: Choose the right tech stack (e.g., programming languages, frameworks, hardware)
Create wireframes for the UI and schematics for the table monitoring hardware
Identify system inputs (e.g., order details, table status, payment info) and outputs (e.g., receipts, reports, table availability)
Plan system architecture for both web app and hardware integration

process.title: Design & Prototyping
details: Develop high-fidelity UI mockups based on wireframes
Design database schema for orders, tables, menu items, and user accounts
Build a clickable prototype for the ordering flow
Create hardware prototype for table occupancy detection
Test prototypes with a small group of users to gather feedback
Refine designs and system features based on usability testing results

process.title: Implementation & Launch
details: Develop the frontend (web app interface) and backend (order processing, database, API)
Integrate hardware sensors with backend for real-time table status updates
Conduct system integration testing between hardware and web app
Implement security features (authentication, role-based access)
Provide staff training and create user manuals
Gather feedback post-launch and plan for future updates
